title.narrative: START Network Crisis and Disaster Risk Financing 2019

description.narrative: These funds be used to innovate crisis and disaster financing methods amongst civil society organisations and frontline humanitarian actors. It will improve financial preparedness of countries in crisis enabling earlier responses that can protect assets lives and livelihoods. This will improve the way humanitarian responses are planned and delivered by governments and wider humanitarian actors.

mailing-address.narrative: 1 Saint Johns Lane, London EC1M 4AR, United Kingdom

description.narrative: 1. Authorities & wider stakeholders are better prepared in advance of crises through provision of global public goods (information, training and toolkits) & a local coalition of humanitarian actors with plans and pre-positioned financing, that can assume a clearer role within national preparedness strategies. (utilisation of Start tools and products by national authorities, evidence of ex-ante collaboration)
# of operational disaster risk financing systems currently live

title.narrative: 1.1b # of NGOs involved in each operational disaster risk financing system and are ready to implement projects should the system trigger (disaggregated by national and international)

description.narrative: # of NGOs
1. The Start Network have established and tested an operational framework for designing, building and implementing disaster risk financing systems at the country level
1.1 Operational, legal and compliance guidelines and templates to support NGOs to implement disaster risk financing systems created at global level, for contextualisation at national level
1.2 # of countries where NGOs have DRF strategies, contingency plans and operational protocols in place
2. Technically appropriate triggers and data analytics for DRF are developed and tested by NGOs
2.1 # of toolkit resources to guide NGOs in conducting hazard, risk and vulnerability analysis created at the global level, for contextualisation at the national level

2.2a # of countries with data models and/or early warning systems in place developed for priority hazards identified by in country Start Network members and windows of opportunity for action, created in partnership between Start members and forecasting experts
2.2b Number of individual data models and/or early warning models adopted by Start Network members in operational countries

comment.narrative: data models for Pakistan drought and Madagascar drought
